commands.name: dir
commands.detailedDescription: The dir command displays a list of files and subdirectories in a directory. Without parameters, it displays the disk's volume label and serial number, followed by a list of directories and files on the disk.

commonOptions.description: Use bare format (no heading or summary)
Display thousands separator in file sizes
Same as wide but files sorted by column
Display files in specified directory and subdirectories
Display short names for non-8.3 files

examples.description: List all files in current directory

commands.name: copy
commands.detailedDescription: The copy command copies one or more files from one location to another. It can also be used to combine files and create new files from the command line.

commonOptions.description: Verify that new files are written correctly
Use short filename if available when copying
Copy networked files in restartable mode
Allow destination file to be created decrypted

commands.name: xcopy
commands.detailedDescription: Extended copy command that copies files and directories, including subdirectories. More powerful than the basic copy command with additional options for attributes, empty directories, and more.

commonOptions.description: Copy directories and subdirectories except empty ones
Copy directories and subdirectories, including empty ones
Assume destination is directory if copying multiple files
Copy files changed on or after specified date
Copy only files that already exist in destination

commands.name: move
commands.description: Move files and rename files and directories
commands.detailedDescription: The move command moves one or more files from one directory to another directory. It can also be used to rename files and directories.

commands.name: del
commands.detailedDescription: The del (or erase) command deletes one or more files. Be careful as deleted files typically cannot be recovered without special software.

commonOptions.description: Prompt for confirmation before deleting each file
Delete specified files from all subdirectories
Quiet mode, do not ask for confirmation
Select files to delete based on attributes

commands.name: mkdir
commands.detailedDescription: The mkdir (or md) command creates a directory. It can create multiple levels of directories in one command.

commands.name: rmdir
commands.detailedDescription: The rmdir (or rd) command removes a directory. By default, the directory must be empty unless you use the /S option.

commonOptions.description: Remove the directory and all its contents
Quiet mode, do not ask for confirmation

commands.name: attrib
commands.detailedDescription: The attrib command displays, sets, or removes attributes assigned to files or directories. Attributes include Read-only (R), Archive (A), System (S), and Hidden (H).

commonOptions.description: Process files in current folder and subfolders

commands.name: type
commands.description: Display the contents of a text file
commands.detailedDescription: The type command displays the contents of a text file or files. It's useful for quickly viewing file contents without opening an editor.

commands.name: ipconfig
commands.detailedDescription: The ipconfig command displays all current TCP/IP network configuration values and can refresh DHCP and DNS settings. It's essential for network troubleshooting.

commonOptions.description: Release the IP address for the specified adapter
Renew the IP address for the specified adapter
Refresh all DHCP leases and re-register DNS names

commands.name: ping
commands.detailedDescription: The ping command sends ICMP echo request packets to a target host and listens for echo reply packets. It's used to test network connectivity and measure round-trip time.

commonOptions.description: Number of echo requests to send

commands.name: tracert
commands.detailedDescription: The tracert command traces the route that packets take to reach a destination. It shows each hop along the path and the time taken for each hop.

commonOptions.description: Do not resolve addresses to hostnames
Maximum number of hops to search
Wait timeout in milliseconds for each reply

commands.name: nslookup
commands.detailedDescription: The nslookup command queries DNS servers to find DNS details, including IP addresses of a particular computer, MX records for a domain, and more.

commands.name: netstat
commands.detailedDescription: The netstat command displays network connections, routing tables, interface statistics, masquerade connections, and multicast memberships.

commonOptions.description: Display all connections and listening ports
Display executable involved in creating connections
Display addresses and ports in numerical form

commands.name: systeminfo
commands.detailedDescription: The systeminfo command displays detailed configuration information about a computer, including hardware, network adapter, and OS configuration.

commands.name: tasklist
commands.detailedDescription: The tasklist command displays a list of currently running processes on a local or remote computer, along with their process IDs, memory usage, and more.

commonOptions.description: List services hosted in each process

commands.name: taskkill
commands.detailedDescription: The taskkill command terminates one or more processes by process ID or image name. It can forcefully terminate processes that don't respond to normal termination.

commands.name: chkdsk
commands.detailedDescription: The chkdsk command checks the file system and file system metadata of a volume for logical and physical errors. It can also fix errors when specified.

commonOptions.description: Locate bad sectors and recover readable information
Perform less vigorous index checking (NTFS only)
Skip checking cycles within folder structure (NTFS only)

commands.name: sfc
commands.detailedDescription: The sfc (System File Checker) command scans and verifies the integrity of all protected system files and replaces incorrect versions with correct Microsoft versions.

commonOptions.description: Scan and repair system files immediately
Scan for integrity violations without repairing

commands.name: net user
commands.detailedDescription: The net user command creates and modifies user accounts on computers. When used without parameters, it lists the user accounts on the computer.

commands.name: shutdown
commands.detailedDescription: The shutdown command allows you to shut down or restart local or remote computers one at a time. It provides various options for logging off users, shutting down, or restarting.

commands.name: reg
commands.detailedDescription: The reg command performs operations on registry subkeys and values. It can query, add, delete, copy, save, and restore registry entries.

commands.name: sc
commands.detailedDescription: The sc command communicates with the Service Control Manager to configure, query, stop, start, and manage Windows services.

commands.name: wmic
commands.detailedDescription: WMIC is a command-line interface to Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) that allows you to query and manage Windows systems. Note: WMIC is deprecated in Windows 11 and later.

commands.name: powercfg
commands.detailedDescription: The powercfg command controls power settings and generates detailed reports about power usage, battery life, and sleep issues on the system.

commands.name: cipher
commands.description: Encrypt or decrypt files and folders
commands.detailedDescription: The cipher command displays or alters the encryption of directories and files on NTFS volumes. It can also be used to securely overwrite deleted data.

commonOptions.description: Perform operation in directory and subdirectories
Remove data from unused disk space
Create new encryption key for user

commands.name: arp
commands.detailedDescription: The arp command displays and modifies entries in the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) cache, which contains IP-to-MAC address mappings.

commands.name: route
commands.description: Display and modify network routing tables
commands.detailedDescription: The route command displays and modifies the entries in the local IP routing table. It's used to manually configure network routes.

commands.name: format
commands.description: Format a disk for use with Windows
commands.detailedDescription: The format command formats a disk for use with Windows. It creates a new file system on the specified volume. Warning: This erases all data on the volume.

commonOptions.description: Files created will be compressed by default (NTFS only)

commands.name: diskpart
commands.detailedDescription: DiskPart is a powerful disk partitioning utility that allows you to manage disks, partitions, and volumes. It runs in its own command interpreter.

commonOptions.description: Remove all partitions from selected disk

examples.command: diskpart > create partition primary > format fs=ntfs quick

commands.name: gpupdate
commands.detailedDescription: The gpupdate command refreshes local and Active Directory-based Group Policy settings, including security settings.

commonOptions.description: Log off after update if required
